reviewerName: Bartok Kinski "A casual stroll through the lu...
reviewText: This movie is the epitome of '70's custom van culture flicks. If you're looking for van culture, this is a very bad choice.Made at the pinnacle of the tiresomely simple 1970's van culture craze, this low-budget action flick follows custom van driver Clint Morgan (Mark Schneider) in his dumb van.The production values are low and the story flavorless, even the hokey action scenes aren't original enough to be amusing on any level.However, its low-budget custom van culture camp, generic humor and (thankfully) short running time save the film as an unintentional 70's comedic piece.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The seventies sucked - I was there for part of it, they were awful. My parents were in the 70's well into the 80's. This movie, though, makes the case that the late 70's were America's Belle Époque.It's a "van movie," Meaning it exists solely because custom vans were a fad for a while there. Carpeted interiors, 70's-style lounge furniture for drinking and doin' DRUGS on, beds (for SEX!) - the vans back then were pretty cool, actually. Sigh.See?  Right there - this stuff speaks to you on a very primal level. The theme song sings our souls: "I don't mind I'm not a wealthy man/ coz I'd rather be ridin' high in my Supervan..." SUPERVAN splices late-70's custom-van culture into the teen-sex-comedy template and the result is pure crap. But crap with charm! The time-capsule aspect alone is worth the price of admission, and the showcasing of a multitude of too-sweet rides is another one in the plus column.The comedy is bad. BAD. Cringeworthy to an "I'm not even mad - that's amazing" extent. The van full of gay men, JEEsus GOHD! don't get the opportunity to camp up the movie nearly enough, and there are a few characters that give one the feeling that their scenes were cut. Yes, their scenes were terrible, but I wanted to see what kind of hijinx an oversexed blonde-maybe-hooker can get up to at a Van-in. I want to KNOW! I might even have traded a shot of the gay men running in terror from the horny farmer's daughters for it. No I wouldn't.I haven't even mentioned the futuristic title beast, Vandora. Look at the box cover, you get the idea. Watch it and think of how uncomfortable this thing would be to drive - hunching over to avoid the slope of the windshield, that 1st-generation-Nintendo-controller-sized steering "wheel"...And then there's Vince. Vince is The Bad Guy. Our heroine's ex, and The Man's right hand, Vince has a great 70's 'stache and is possibly the only character in the film with any SOUL. Skip Riley turns in SUPERVAN's only...performance as the ultimate sleazy 70's makeout man.The Man: "You look...familiar. Did...you ever date my daughter?"Vince: "...is she under 65?"Vince should have had his own series, him and his van "Gunrunner." It would have been the Anti-Knight Rider.The heroine wears a tight knit turtleneck for much of the film, and it must have been cold on the set; SUPERVAN doesn't have a magic center, it has two. The van has a laser. The "Vanners" fight The Man, complete with police cars flipping over highway berms. When the protagonist Clint tells his dad "My dream ain't your dream, dad! I have a chance to really DO something!" (because he's going to a van-in, MAN!) a melancholy version of the "Supervan" theme plays. The nerd character gets laid - in a THREE-WAY. A girl in a wet t-shirt tries to pry Charles Bukowski's arm from around her waist. Yes, it's really really him. There's a song that goesFreak out! (freak out)FREAK OUT!Baby, why don't you do what you're toldFreak out!(freak out)FREAK OUT!Give it to me, let the good times roll...When's the last time the good times ROLLED for any of you people? Exactly - the 1970's.Yes, it's worth buying even though it looks like a worn VHS (which, ironically, would have been some pretty fancy technology when this film was made).
summary: I'd rather be ridin' high in my Supervan

reviewText: If you thought director Lamar Card set a personal worst record with "Disco Fever," you haven't seen "Supervan." This is a movie that makes the buffoonery of the 1970's crystal clear with everything from a solar-powered supervan, to horrible hairstyles and clothes, a drunken Charles Bukowski, and some of the absolute worst music ever put on a soundtrack. Filmed in Kansas City, the plot shows us a young man, Clint Morgan (Mark Schneider,) who has left his lucrative job at a filling station to pursue his dreams of superstardom by winning the $5,000 grand prize at a custom van competition called simply "Freakout." This is supposedly a huge event as we see a minor convoy of hideous custom vans and hear a lot of beyond-idiotic CB lingo indicating the hugeness of scope involved. In reality there's maybe twenty vans or so there, and some of the signs for the event are hand-lettered on poster board.After the execrable opening theme song ("I'd rather be ridin' high in my Supervan!") Clint runs afoul of some very lame bikers over the affections of Karen Trenton (Katie Saylor,) while for some reason his van and one of the biker's bikes are crushed in a rogue car crushing machine. (I'm not clear on how exactly that happened, but now that I think about it, I don't care.) There's lots of jaw-droppingly bad dialogue ("They say a pirate's spirit never dies...") and extraordinarily bad acting. Luckily Clint knows an MIT-educated genius, Boseley (Tom Kindle,) who designs him a solar-powered supervan named "Vandora," actually designed by the king of car customizers George Barris. Barris, who made the original Batmobile and worked on shows such as "The Munsters," "My Mother the Car," and "Knight Rider," also appears as himself here as the chief judge of Freakout. As an aside, I'm not certain that Vandora is really ready for primetime as she makes a very annoying and loud high-pitched squealing sound (due to photosynthesis, I guess) that literally made my cats leave the room. Forewarned is forearmed.Vandora is the bane of an evil capitalist (of course) with interests in both vans and big oil, T.B. Trenton (Morgan Woodward.) It will probably not strike you as an amazing coincidence that the girl Clint rescued is Mr. Trenton's daughter, nor will it surprise you to know that Trenton has plans to dispose of Clint. But first, the plot has to take a break to allow a horrible musical interlude and a water balloon toss to pad the running time (this concept becomes an unfortunate trend.) Mr. Trenton then gets the sheriff on the lookout for Vandora, and comedy ensues. My vote for worst scene in the film is for the sheriff's outhouse ploy, and my vote for single stupidest plot twist in the film goes to Vandora using her laser beam (!) to break Clint out of jail. (You just have to see this to appreciate it.) Because the plot was so thin, running time was added anywhere conceivable. Don't believe me? Just watch how long it takes extras to put up a tent in mud. Oh, the drama!Eventually (after more mud-related drama,) Vandora wins the prize from Mr. Trenton, sponsor of the event. (Oh the hilarity....) As the film closes, the movie takes a sudden turn for the serious and features a truly dreadful closing love theme from "Supervan" about the nature of love and life. (Note particularly the rhyme scheme issues in said song.) The conclusion exposes the essential dichotomy of "Supervan." It is unsure what percentage of the film is comedy and what percentage is drama, and the two switch back and forth seemingly at random. It would be unwatchable if it weren't so relentlessly campy.The "Cheezy Flicks" transfer has many flaws in it, but I am guessing this movie was not lovingly preserved by anyone. The DVD features previews for other movies, and an "Intermission" feature, which is actually better than "Supervan." In spite of the obvious inclination to give this film one star, I just can't: it has so much unintended hilarity in it that it deserves three stars for eye-rolling camp value and humorous 1970's cultural artifacts that can really only be appreciated in hindsight. If you are a fan of inane B-movies, this is definitely for you. If you are a fan of well-crafted films with logical plots and good acting, you need to pass this one by just as quickly as you can.
summary: Unintended Hilarity Courtesy Of The Unlamented 1970's Van Culture
Title: N/A
